bibl.title: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, April 14, 1941

div1.p: Truby finds Agramonte's statements greatly exaggerated. He also faults the sketch proposed for the yellow fever painting.

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, April 14, 1941
div1.opener:
Albert E. Truby
145 Laurel Street
San Francisco, California
April 14/41
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
I was going to send you a
letter to Florida but I have had a
miserable 10 days with a nasal sinus
and really was not able to do anything.

It is getting on nicely now and
I thought I would be able to get
this to Rochester about the time of your
return there.

I have everything you sent me
including the small maps. The Hammeter
book went on to Gen. Kean by Railroad
express about a week ago. My comments
therein are frank and honest and express
my opinions as they were formed 40 yrs.
ago. I have no idea if Gen. Kean
formed similar opinions or not. I
fully believe that Carroll's statements
after Reed's death, and those of Hammeter and,
others influenced Kean to accept Agramonte's
statement in the Senate Doc. But I shall
always feel that he must have known
at the time that they were at least exagerated
and far from the truth. I have not written
to Pinto and will await your efforts to
draw out his statements. Then I do want
to ask him a few questions.

Mr Kellogg sent me a copy of the
sketch by the steps of the medical officers
quarters. I have not made any
comments as my views have been
made clear and I do not want to
influence those on the ground.
Frankly, I have much fault to find
with the last sketch. I think they should
take more time and give the matter
careful consideration.

Lyster's remarks to Ross are new
to me but I give them very little
credence. Ross must have been in
Panama a dozen or more years
after Lazear died. Gorgas and others
would have quoted Lister years before
if the statement were true. Lyster came
to Cuba in 1899 as a Contract Surgeon
and in 1900 took the army examination
for a commission in the Med. Corps. He
passed and Gorgas took him into his
office doing Sanitory work. Lyster was
a relative of Mrs Gorgas. He was not
a Yellow Fever expert or even “Expert,”
Perhaps Kean can give you more
light on Lyster. He died a
few years ago.

J. H. Andrus has written up
his story and asked my permission
to quote some of the information
I gave you for your address at
W.&.J. I gave him permission
to do so, but suggested that he
also ask if you had any suggestions
objections. No doubt you have
heard from him. It is remarkable
how he does such things considering
his condition. I saw him at
the Walter Reed Hospital 7 or 8 years
ago and did not expect he would
live very long.

I will be interested in learning
of your trip and what new
things you may have unearthed
in Cuba.
div1.closer:
Very Sincerely Albert E. Truby (Over)
AC
T
I have a nice letter from Col.
Willis stating that they would set
up the model to scale on a piece
of actual terrain as soon as
the weather & their work would
permit. Willis has just been
made a Brigadier General and
suppose he will be placed in Command
at Carlisle.
In your last letter you asked
if I knew where the 1899 or 1900 maps
of Camp Columbia could be found. Also
the keys for same. I do not know.
Suggest you write to the General
Staff map. Collection (Officer in Charge)
and ask if they Love them. Address
him at the War Dept. Washington.
